"Strategies that require low cognitive effort—such as passively listening to a lecture—are often perceived by students to be more effective than active strategies such as hands-on experimentation and group problem-solving. The group dynamic can make students feel frustrated and “painfully aware of their lack of understanding,” but the study concluded that the more effort and struggle involved—hallmarks of a student-centered, active approach—the more students learned."

SLC is not lecture based. Our community thrives on authentic tasks that mimic real world working situations. Students learn to struggle through complex tasks as a crew- just as they will be expected to do when they enter the work force.

We are proud of our rigorous expeditions and our Crew communities, cornerstones of our program that any of our students could tell you all about. We believe this approach to learning not only makes for a better school, but also prepares our scholars to be 21st century leaders.

There is only one other EL school in Minnesota, located in the cities- a few in Wisconsin, none in North Dakota, South Dakota, Iowa, etc. Schoolcraft is excited to continue to offer this unique opportunity to K-8 learners.

We get asked a lot-- "What is a charter school, anyway?" Charter schools are public schools (there is no tuition, and anyone can come!), and our purpose is to be innovative. Schoolcraft was formed almost 20 years ago centered around the idea of developing humans to be lifelong learners who had the knowledge and compassion to navigate a complex and changing world.

In order to fulfill this mission, we partnered with Expeditionary Learning (now known as EL Education). In 2015, NPR made a radio documentary about EL's roots in Outward Bound and how the model has developed over the years to be known as one of the best education models in the nation. Check it out!

Happy July, Schoolcrafters! We have some new staff we would like to introduce, starting with our new school counselor, Belinda!

Belinda Schermerhorn lives in Bagley with her husband, Jeff and their two teenage boys. She received her undergraduate degree at Bemidji State University and her Masters in School Counseling at the University of North Dakota. In her free time she loves to cheer on her boys at their baseball, football, and hockey games. She also enjoys cooking, spending time in her flower beds, and being with her family. Belinda has years of experience working in schools and mental health, and we are so excited to have her diverse experiences benefitting our students this fall.

Belinda says, “ I am excited to be joining the Schoolcraft Learning Community staff. I feel very fortunate to be working in an educational community so strongly rooted in expeditionary and socio-emotional learning.”

Welcome to our crew, Belinda!

The 2016-2017 school year I applied to be a substitute teacher at SLC. I ended up receiving an offer from them to be a full time paraprofessional which I took. I'm excited to join the staff again this year but as a Special Education teacher.

I love the way the school is set up and how it incorporates the outdoors into teaching the students."

Welcome back, Markki! We're so excited to have you!
